1.text: Use the backward loop cast on if you are new to knitting.

2.text: Use the long-tail cast on if you want an even and somewhat elastic edge.

3.text: Know when to use the provisional cast on.

4.text: Make a slipknot and slide it onto your knitting needle.

5.text: Hold the needle in your hand and wrap the yarn around your thumb from behind the working yarn.

6.text: Bring the needle in front of your thumb and the strand of yarn.

7.text: Slip the needle under the yarn around your thumb.

8.text: Pull your thumb out and tug on both strands of yarn.

9.text: Push the loop down towards the slipknot, and adjust if necessary.

10.text: Keep repeating the steps until you have the number of stitches the pattern requires.

11.text: Determine how much tail yarn you will need.

12.text: Attach the yarn to the needle.

13.text: Tug the needle gently downward to form a loop around your thumb.

14.text: Poke the tip of the needle through the loop around your thumb.

15.text: Grab the strand that's coming off of your finger.

16.text: Use the needle to pull tail back through the thumb loop.

17.text: Pull your thumb out and gently tighten the loop around the needle.

18.text: Push the stitch down towards the slipknot.

19.text: Keep repeating the steps until you have the number of stitches you need.

20.text: Make a chain stitch using a crochet needle two times the size of your knitting needle.

21.text: Pull the chain off the crochet needle.

22.text: Hold the chain in your left hand and the needle in your right hand.

23.text: Stick the tip of the needle into the third bump of the crochet chain.

24.text: Drape the  ball end of the yarn over the tip of the needle.

25.text: Use the needle to pull the yarn through the bump.

26.text: Repeat the steps until you have cast on the number of stitches that the pattern requires.
